ygData.subject: Crossover
ygData.msgSnippet: Just thinking out loud... In biology chromosomes in cells exist in pairs such that for each gene there are two variants - a maternal and paternal variant.

Subject: Crossover
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770077; y=R7kAwm89eldGdRc6VsOQBRbMwWpvzVoVI_ikrNXDIgRZ9b-VdEbJ
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod
From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>


--94eb2c061b40482c7c05638e638d
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="UTF-8"

Just thinking out loud...

In biology chromosomes in cells exist in pairs such that for each gene
there are two variants - a maternal and paternal variant. Crossover occurs
between these two variants when sperm and eggs cells are formed, and *not*
at fertilisation time. It is the sperm and eggs that contain randomized
combinations of the maternal and paternal genes. Fertilisation then
combines the 'randomized' chromosomes from sperm and egg to once again form
a pair.

I'm wondering if this is functionally equivalent to how crossover is
typically performed in evolutionary computing, whereby each parent has a
single genetic sequence and crossover occurs at the equivalent of
fertilisation time in biology.

Seems to me that the biological way is keeping more possibilities open by
keeping twice as much genetic material in each organism compared to the EC
approach.

E.g. say you had a bad gene in one of your gene variants. In the EC
approach your children each have a 50% chance of inheriting and expressing
that gene. In biology they still have a 50% chance of inheriting it, but it
might not get expressed because each child has another non-bad copy of it.

Interested to know if anyone has a view on this. Is the biological way just
a quirk of how the mechanisms evolved, or is there a benefit to doing it
that way?

Colin.

--94eb2c061b40482c7c05638e638d
Content-Type: text/html; charset="UTF-8"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
